newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek yield curve collapses on fx inflows at close.
newsitem.headline: Greek yield curve collapses on fx inflows at close.

text.p: Greek and foreign players rushed to open new ecu/drachma positions driving ecu/drachma sharply lower to 306 and pulling implied drachma rates down 10 to 30 basis points with the drop more pronounced in longer tenors, dealers said.
"Forex inflows have pushed the yield curve sharply lower," said a foreign bank dealer. "The drop is about 10 basis points in short dates and 30 basis points in longer tenors."

A total of more than 200 million ecus and 75 million marks were sold at the fixing where ecu/drachma dropped to 305.75 when a major foreign bank came out selling 200 million ecus but recovered to close at 306 as the same bank bought back 130 million ecus.
Dealers said more forex inflows followed suit after the fixing.
Other dealers said the opening of new ecu/drachma positions and the roll-over of maturing ones accounted for the forex inflows that had sent one-year implied drachma rates down to 11.35 percent.

"One-year implied drachma rates are trading at 11.35 percent from 11.75 percent on Thursday," said a money dealer at a private bank. "There is plenty of liquidity from the forex as new ecu/drachma positions are opened and it weighs down on the yield curve."

The central bank's reputation in navigating ecu/drachma succesfully through stormy weather and the still high interest rate differentials favouring the drachma account for the willingness of market players to take the risk in ecu/drachma.
The central bank kept its overnight bid unchanged at 12.40 percent. Market participants have been expecting the central bank to slash its intervention bid soon.

Bond dealers said there was modest to thin buying interest for non-taxable bonds in the secondary market mainly fuelled by retailers who wanted to get higher net yields that those offered by the taxable 12-month T-bills.
The 12-month T-bills issued on January 2 offered a gross yield of 11.20 percent or a net yield of 10.36 percent after the 7.5 percent withholding tax.
The finance ministry said in a statement that T-bill sales amounted to about 400 billion drachmas exceeding expiries of 335 billion drachmas.
The mark was quoted at 157.95/05 drachmas from Friday's 158.390 fix, the dollar at 245.14/24 drachmas from 247.030 and the Ecu at 305.41/51 from 306.000 drachmas.
